answer_html: So the y-intercept is the same as the x-intercept, \((0,0)\)
answer_latex: So the y-intercept is the same as the x-intercept, $(0,0)$
hints_html: Recall that \(f(x)\) has a y-intercept when x = 0 and an x-intercept when the function is zero.
hints_latex:
Recall that $f(x)$ has a y-intercept when \emph{x = 0} and an
x-intercept when the function is zero.
hints_raw: Recall that <math>f(x)</math> has a y-intercept when ''x = 0'' and an x-intercept when the function is zero.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
x-intercept

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)\end{aligned}\]

has an x-intercept when \(f(x) = 0\). So

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\end{aligned}\]

Cross multiplying gives \(2x^2 = 0\), which simplifies to \(x = 0\). So the x-intercept is \((0,0)\)

y-intercept

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)\end{aligned}\]

has an y-intercept when \(x = 0\). Plugging in x = 0 gives \(f(0) = 0\).

So the y-intercept is the same as the x-intercept, \((0,0)\)
sols_raw:
'''x-intercept''': <math>f(x)</math> has an x-intercept when <math>f(x) = 0</math>.  So

: <math>0 = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}</math>

Cross multiplying gives <math>2x^2 = 0</math>, which simplifies to <math>x = 0</math>.  So the x-intercept is <math>(0,0)</math>

'''y-intercept''': <math>f(x)</math> has an y-intercept when <math>x = 0</math>.  Plugging in ''x = 0'' gives <math>f(0) = 0</math>.  

So the y-intercept is the same as the x-intercept, <math>(0,0)</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\end{aligned}\]

(b) Find all the x- and y-intercepts of \(f\).
statement_raw:
Let
:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}
</math>

'''(b)''' Find all the ''x''- and ''y''-intercepts of &fnof;.
